reviewText:
This is the worst idle game I've ever played. I hesitate to even call it a game since it has almost no graphics, and looks like a business application. Why is it bad?
The UI is poorly done, and it doesn't adhere to GUI conventions. For example, there are a lot of things that look like buttons, but they effectively serve as tabs, because clicking them changes the page that's displayed. Just, unlike actual tab controls, there is no visual indication of this whatsoever.
The game is rather complex, and the numerous pieces of information it displays and the actions you can do are all stuffed into the multitude of hidden pages. There is no simple, sensible layout of all this.
Speaking of the game's complexity, when you first run it, you'll be greeted by the FAQ page. Its wall of text will try to explain some of the game's multitude of concepts and mechanics to you. Why? Because there is no tutorial! Instead, aside from the FAQ, there are tooltips on all the UI elements, briefly explaining what they do. You're going to be playing detective for a while to piece it all together.
BTW, this game has been out on Kongregate for a while, and a large number of the positive Steam reviews you see here are from experienced Kongregate players. The game is by no means as good as the current rating implies.

reviewText:
Pros:
- an incremental game not fueled by an autoclicker is refreshing
- interesting goals and objectives to meet
- plenty of content to last for hundreds of hours

Cons:
- cluttered UI makes the game more difficult to learn
- character art leaves a lot to be desired, no matter what unlocks i get for my goddess she will still look kinda derpy
- not much incentive to play due to shabby character art and widely spaced milestones and achievements

Although there doesn't seem to be much to unlock, i still recommend giving this game a try.

reviewText:
Product received for free

40 hours in. Why am i doing this to myself?
I did find that i quite like the tooltips. they did give me a few chuckles. However, i found a few more glaring design flaws.
Why is there a feature to limit the max amount of levels on skills, but NOT one to limit the max amount of creations? this means i jhave to watch very carefully if i want to make soil and have some rocks left over, or make air and keep light. Compare this to the absolutely useless ability to stop gaining infinitely extendable resources with zero penalites for making them, tranings and skills.
Also, the fact that pet food's tooltip seems to imply that it actively HURTS your pet isawful, and makes me not want to use it. i assume it doesn't but i'd rather not take risks.
Speaking of pets, why is food so expensive? just let me buy it in divinity!

24 hours in. Haven't progressed much at all, due do a few factors.
1. Offline progression either doesn't work, or is nonexistent.can't tell you which yet, but i'm leaning towards the latter. EDIT: IT WORKS NOW, dunno why it wasn't before.
2. you know how in every other clicker/idle, if it has a prestiege feature, this feature is something you should hold off on using until quite a while in? this game wants, no, DEMANDS you use it constantly.
3. grinding the clonecap down is tedious and boring, and it doesn't appear there is a way to speed up your ability cooldowns in the special minigame. ALMOST FORGOT: it is super counter-intuitive. i get what the dev was going for, i really do. he wanted you to have to keep your skill power and cap grinding time balanced. However, what really just ends up happening is that your low level skills you need to decrease the cap for grow with level, meaning that they do no damage, meaning using them solely to fight (one of the only reasons to use special) will not work. you are literally better off waiting 24 hours in auto before progressing (see point 1) in order to have decent enough skills to grind.
Not sure i'll progress much further before quitting, only redeeming factor so far is the decent fanfiction unlocked by beating a boss.

reviewText:
First off, I'll tell you I played on Kong long before its Steam release.  It's not a game for everyone.  But if you've got time on the side to play around a bit, and you liked playing with numbers as a kid, you just might fall in love.

The start is rocky, and the pace is cruel.   But there's plenty of willing helpers in chat, as well as guides and established forums with loads of information.  And just when you've reached the end of the hit list, the real game opens up.  ItRtG has enough different types of challenges and goals that it can fit any schedule or play style.

The best part, IMO, is the complexity of the different features, without any being game-breaking.  A good idle game to keep a thinker's brain busy.

Just don't come in looking for instant satisfaction.  This is an investment of time, not button mashing.

reviewText:
When I first noticed the game it was on steam's main page. I checked it out, noticed it was free and even though there are some what you could call 'pay to win' elements (but not really) I wanted to give it a try. And well, as you can see, I already pumped over thirty hours in the game.

So the most obvious question you ask yourself after the previous parargraph is 'if the game is pay to win, then what do you mean by that?' or something along those lines anyway. Well, there is something called 'god power' that you get by defeating gods the first time and then every time after a certain point.

To clarify that a bit, there are about.. I think eight to ten gods that only give a god power the first time and then you get only a god power starting from (as an example) god number eleven. That will get you a point every time.

Now, these points can be used to increase your stats permenantly. See, you progress into the game mainly through the use of shadow clones. (not related to Naruto in any way shape or form) but the idea behind it still fits.

Anyway, you use shadow clones to fight monsters, to train and to build monuments. the first two you can do from the start but the latter is only available after defeating a certain god.

An additional feature is something called 'rebirth' it will reset your progress to zero BUT you keep your stats. That means that when you struggled to defeat the first god, the first time around, you'll defeat him in seconds flat by the time you rebirth a few times.

Now, this game is an 'idle' game which means that you don't have to pay it much attention. In fact, you could leave it alone for a few days and you would have made a very big amount of progress stats wise. The bigger your stats before you rebirth, the bigger your advantages will be the next time you rebirth.

All by all, if you have time to waste, to check the game every now and then and see progress every time you do, then this game is definetly for you.

But if you don't like bigger numbers then you ever realistically use in real life (like EVER) then don't bother with this. After a while the numbers get so big that it gets absolutely ridicilous. I mean, I knew that after billion came trillion but after that I didn't care too much. I mean, what need does a regular person have for bigger numbers then that?

Now, story wise you can read a story but it is only written up to a certain point at this point. It requires your imagination to tell the story and even if it was finished, the story is 'meh' at best and 'oh my god, that was the biggest waste of time to read in my life' at the worst.

I want to stress that this isn't a game that you leave open for hours at a time. In fact, closing it and leaving it alone rewards you by increasing your creation stats by three hundred percent. (300 % !!!)

Trust me, that's good.

My conclusion is that this is an excellent game to waste some time if you are bored and got nothing better to do. But I would still recommend it. Hell, I would even be willing to pay a small amount for it. Not much, definetly not above five euros and probably not even that. Not because I'm cheap or anything, but because the nature of the game, while amusing isn't worth more then that.

Kingdark

reviewText:
Addicting...I'm not sure why it is so fun to watch numbers get bigger. I was hooked on this almost as soon as I started. Coming off of a recent Cookie Clicker binge, I guess I'm just not ready to move on from these idle games.
I think the reason these types of games are fun is becuase of the constant  goals you can set and accomplish.

The game also is not a huge time-sink. You set your clones doing work, and then you focus on something else for a few hours. You come back and now you're strong enough to kill the next god.
The pacing of the game is also really well done; you're always unlocking new things even towards the end, and each rebirth feels like a new game but less grindy.

The game is also very transparent in how things are calculated. It doesn't just throw you in and make you deal with how things work, it very plainly tells you all of the calculations and formulas that are used, so you don't have to waste time searching the web for that stuff if you're a min/max addict like me.

And whats that? This game is only $0.00? (€0.00 for my friends across the pond)
That is free. This game is free. I like free. Free is best.
This dev is also not aggressive about the fact that the game is free. Sure, there's things you can buy in the game, but the dev doesn't even attempt to force those things on you or throw it in your face, and I really respect that.

Try this game out, let it run while you do other work.

reviewText:
Idling to Rule the Gods is a pretty neat idle game.

It's pretty user friendly but at the start it might make new players feel overwhelmed (but some great games do also.)

I do recommend this game for many reasons.

Pros
-----

Free (as almost all idle/clicker games)
A pretty rich story despite being an idle game (though I haven't played many so I'm not sure.)
A lot in which the player can do w/o feeling too overwhelmed (fighting, training, creating, and dueling with your pets.)
Daily free draws (in which you can get any one thing, even more free draws.)
Some pretty badass music (imo.)
Super friendly UI in almost all cases.
A pretty fast start actually, beating Hyperion took not even close to an hour and once that's done you can steamroll Itztil after a rebirth (in a quick amount of time from training.)
Little details in which the player can change the color of the layout and dress their person.
The art is nice actually. Some DA ♥♥♥♥?" ♥♥♥♥ off

this is some nice art and fits with this kind of game.

Now of course the cons because almost all games have some.

reviewText:
So this game has a been of a bit of an addiction for me the last several days since release. There's a lot more to it then one would think.

First off this isn't a CLICKER game. Not like Clicker Heroes, Time Clickers, etc. There are some parts where you click a lot of but it's mainly focused around idling and waiting for stuff. I know, strange that a game with the word IDLING in the title has a lot to do with IDLING, isn't it? Of course you could be an idiot and leave a negative review for just that reason.

Anyway, so here's how it works. You start off as pretty much just a normal guy, stuck on a planet after we humans destroyed our home world....for the 17th time. You end up in a world and universe ruled by powerful gods. Being the last survivor of a war against the god Hyperion, you end up developing your own godlike powers and start to challenge the gods, beginning with Hyperion and progressing up a ladder.

Yes folks this game does indeed have a story, with bits of it being unlocked everytime you defeat one of the gods. Currently the story stops after one of the mid-range gods with nothing remaining for the rest of them, so this might be something that comes in the future hopefully. For now the story that exists is pretty good, as it gives context and reason to your idling.

At its core the game is involved around you training shadow clones, and using these clones to train skills and fight monsters, which in turn raises your own stats. You assign a certain number of clones to each task and wait as your skills get higher. When you're strong enough you challenge a god, and then rinse and repeat until you find you can't beat the next god. At that point you can rebirth" which starts you over but gives you multipliers on your stats; not much different then a lot of other idle games of this style. But there's a fair bit of depth to it
date: which i'll leave you to figure out yourself once you start playing.\n\nA solid 'sit around on your ♥♥♥ and become more powerful then you can imagine' recommendation."

reviewText:
I used to play some other idle games like Cookie Clicker, Clicker heroes and Adventure Capitalist, i loved both of them but that one is, in my opinion even more complexe.

There is always something new to discover, you always have something you can do, you keep unlocking new features to keep you on your toes and how you progress in the game is up to you, it's insanely addicitve and can be really fun.

Since i discovered it, I kept playing it, I can't stop I'm always aiming for something, and when I reach it, I unlock something new, I try it, learn it, fix myself a goal to reach, then by the time I reach it I unlocked an other thing...and this go on again and again, i wasn't expecting something so deep and exctiting.

If you wonder if you should try it or not, DO IT, I would pay for this actually and it's free to play, really 10/10 I love it.

reviewText: The GistIf you read the ABOUT you'll understand the game and find out it has a decent plot. You start off small and go big like every other similar game. After the humans basically destroyed all habitable planets in the known universe, on the last planet they created a space dimension device. Using this device they were able to travel to a different dimension. In this dimension they noticed that the world was ruled and run by gods. The last human survived a long battle with the first god and developed a new ability: shadow clones. You create these clones and train them to basically do everything for you, that includes killing gods.\n\nWhat I thinkOnce starting Idling to Rule the Gods you are sort of confused on what to do at first. There's no visual tutorials that help and show you what you should be doing, how you should be doing it and where you should be doing it at. After some common sense you'll just be clicking these obvious buttons, Build"
hoursPlayed: "Other" - Each button serve their own purpose. You build shadow clones via "Build" (it is automatic). You will then use those built (created) shadow clones in the "Train" and "Fight" tabs to increase your stats.\n\nIf you click the "Other" button you will also notice the "Story" tab. This basically tells you what to do
voteText: but as I said nothing is visual and you have to read (which in today's world a lot of people apparently don't know how to read or don't want to read). I didn't notice the Story button until later on during gameplay.\n\nYou might look at this game and think "Clicker"
votesHelpful: it isn't a clicker. That was my initial thought until I read the tags and didn't see "Clicker". Almost everything is automatic by incrementing clones in a specific skill or fight.\n\nAfter so & so hours of playing I finally defeated a few gods and eventually Rebirth (basically start over with higher multipliers). Don't worry
votesTotal: I Rebirth with pretty decent multiplier values. Any who
votesFunny: after rebirthing I started over again with a nice force and within a few minutes defeated the first god. I'm now at 4 gods defeated
commentsCount: about to be 5. On that note
column16: it honestly didn't take that long to get going. Most of my time playing was just to build up rebirth stats.\n\nThis game is time consuming
column17:
but once you get going it is amazing for such a very simple game.

Rating: 9/10

I recommend this title.

I will make it easier if people don't feel like reading. Below is a pros and cons.

Pros Free to play
Time consuming and what you expect out of this type of game genre
Replay value (includes Rebirth replay)
Great story
Creation boost when the game is offline and you start it back up
Automatic handling
Quite a lot to do
Cons No visual tutorials or anything (maybe story?) explaining what to do at the beginning. There should be some pointers on how to get started.
Pet leveling isn't automatic. You have to constantly monitor pets to recreate custom clones to level it.
Cannot create while the game isn't active (Unless I'm missing something here?).."

reviewText: This game is quite fun if you like idle games. It has a huge amount of depth to it, and while you don't have to spend any money on it to experience the full depth of the game, it is absolutely worth supporting the developer. Even if you don't normally like idle games, it's something fun to do on the side of anything else you're doing on your computer.\n\nFor example, when I was doing schoolwork I would often keep the game open in another tab (I played on the Kong version before this was released) and complete an assignment, and then go change some things around, spend god power, allocate my clones, etc. Then I would go do another assignment, or some reading. It can be a bit intimidating at first, but you'll get the hang of it quickly.

reviewText:
I'll make it short and simple. This game is really friggin deep. it does idle game progression right. There's about 30 different creations(resources) which all have an actual, tangible benefit to you. All the game features interact in really neat ways. Each time you think you're about to stall, there's something right on the horizon to aim for that's cool and new. There's a variety of challenge runs to gain neat perks, and appeal to playing around with the various game mechanics in novel ways. You can play this as active or as idle as you want, and this game has many ways to appeal to either side.


If you liked the depth of gameplay, and discovery from idle games like Anti-Idle: The Game?  This is *the* idle game for you.

reviewText: This game was my life. I used to play this game all the time when it was on Kongregate. This is definitely the sort of game where you need to be patient to be able to do anything at all, but if you put the time into it, new things will unlock, and you will be able to create matter, build monuments, trade things and even convert those matter into planets and the such. And now I can see that there are new features added into the mix; I am really looking forward to playing with that. Overall,Idling to Rule the Gods is definitely something you should leave in the background whilst you do other things, and come back to see how the avatar you" did whilst you were elsewhere. I definitely recommend a try at the very least
date: maybe you can grow to like the charms of this strange little idle game.\n\nEDIT: And now I found out that there are lores
recommended: detailed lores that outlines how you've came to be
hoursPlayed: why you are fighting creatures and gods
voteText: as well as how your powers came to be
helpfulPercent: and how they relates to gods. This is amazing and it tied the different pieces of game mechanics together. I have never expected such a detailed lore for this game
votesHelpful: and now I am more glad than ever to have found this game again years after the last time I played it."

reviewText:
Great idling game if you're into the genre.

Pros:
- Balanced learning curve
- Great depth
- A lot of features
- Achievements
- Keeps you busy though it is called an idling game.
- AFK modus
- Smart auto-toggles (removes the need for creating a macro)
- In-game currency can be earned by playing the game (certainly not p2w)
- reset game function (only use in desperate need)
- (balanced) rebirth/ascend system

Cons:
- Not the most advanced graphics, but that is fine.
- Icons could be a bit more intuitive

10/10 would beat idols again and again and again and again

reviewText:
Not pretty, but rather well made.
I play a lot of idle games, from stuff on Kon, to a few steam ones.  I've seen good, and I have seen junk.  This one is pretty decent, though as I said, not that pretty.

So what is it all about?  Well you idle for an army of clones and materials.  You fight monsters with those.  With clones you train up your HP and str, then fight down gods.  It isn't that bad, and there is a bit of depth to it.  Nothing fancy though.

I must give it marks for presentation, since you have options to change around the UI, and what your character looks like.  If I were TotalBiscuit I'd give the options menu a passing grade for the type of game it is.

Not my favorite of idles, but it isn't bad.  It does have micro transactions, but the game is free. That is really all I can say.
voteText: 7 of 21 people (33%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Product received for free

Hands down my favorite Incremental Game of all time.

All of these reviews trashing this game for its graphics don't seem to understand Incremental and Idle Games. Trimps has no graphics at all, neither does Swarmsim. So tell me, how do they have active cult followings and hundreds of active players?

Idle and Incremental Games don't NEED graphics. The fact that this one has hand drawn art gives it a heck of a lot of charm to me, and if you choose to be a Goddess then you certainly aren't ugly. In my opinion, she's pretty cute, even without cosmetic unlocks ^^;

The progression is deep and will take you a good while, and content is added pretty often. I played a month or two ago on Kong, and now we have pets.

I mean, pets? I'm a puny mortal suplexing Gods and beating the shizzit out of my Shadow Clone Jutsus, and a Mouse adds  a couple hundred power level to me? Sure :D

On a final note, (and hopefully the arrogance and master race level of this little comment doesn't get too bad,) a true fan of Incremental games will see just how much time and effort can be sunk into this game. I'm an absolute $lut for seeing small numbers get big, and this game scratches that itch so very, very nicely...

...At least, until Solomon calls for me again. I can hear His voice now, from the depths of my Library...

You worship false idols. Come back to the loving embrace of Clicker Heroes..."

I...Must...Resist...!!!

Curse you

reviewText: Downloaded it because it looked interesting and found it to be surprisingly fun.  It has a built in IRC client if you want to ask questions, a story, and from the looks of it a lengthy progression.  I should be able to defeat Izanagi soon; the only thing left to figure out is how the pets work.  It was confusing at first, but 20-30 minutes of trying things and reading the FAQ set me off in the right direction.\n\nThis game is not for those that want instant gratification, beautiful graphics, amazing UI design, etc.  This is port of a flash game (it really shows), but regardless I am enjoying it thus far.

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nWell, I played the Kongregate version of the game a little bit, killed the first 5 or so gods, and stopped playing. I got bored multiple times because of the repetitiveness in the game. Same thing over and over. Get strong, kill gods, rebirth, get strong, kill gods, rebirth etc. Nothing much different here. Left the game on for 17 straight hours, got bored, quit. There's a lot more to do than just this, so I reccomend you hop on and actually give the game a chance. I do like it that you can rebirth and become a stronger god. I always like games like this. Reccomendation from me!

Wtf do you want this game to be? It's a ♥♥♥♥ing idle game. Devianart ♥♥♥♥, wtf do you mean? Just because of the game having deviantart artstyle it's ♥♥♥♥? You guys are just ungreatful. The games free also, it's simplistic to, not pay to win (but you can pay to upgrade faster),  and very addicting, so please, don't ♥♥♥♥♥ at this game just because of its simplicity and the way it looks.

Btw, I don't even play this game on kongregate, I didn't even know it was on it in the first place till I saw the reviews.

reviewText:
The trailer was so bizzare that I had to try it...

I just don't see the point.  Guess I'm getting old.

Read guides and forums: Everything was explained with It's an Idle game".  Had to look it up on wikipedia to get an explaination.

"...the game plays itself
date:
including in the player's absence."

Oh right....I have some of those already.  I call them tomato plants.  I can watch them incrementally grow too.  But I can eat them for satisfaction.

I guess this is good for people who can't grow plants or don't have any grass to watch.

I give it a "DBZ sticker on a running stopwatch" out of 10."
